p: Although the magnitude of sequence diversity did not change over time, it was likely that env sequences at later time points had diverged from those sampled earlier. To investigate the temporal pattern of sequence evolution within each animal, all available samples from all three time-points for each animal were pooled and analyzed by maximum likelihood (Fig. 4; FQi). Sixteen of the nineteen (85%) bootstrap-supported clades from FQi contain variants from a single time point only. This pattern was repeatable amongst variants from all other animals; 100%, 80%, 69%, and 63% of bootstrap supported clades consisted of a single time point in animals FDo, FFj, FJo, and FBo, respectively. In an analysis of random trees, the number of matching time-point sequences that comprise a monophyletic group showed a Poisson distribution; 86% of variants did not form monophyletic clades with any other matching time-point variant (i.e., these sequences stood alone). Thus, the observed temporal clustering of SIVsm viral populations does not occur by chance alone (Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, p < 0.01).
